topic.title: Tor error
topic.body: Is it possible to tell zeronet to retry to connect to tor, without restarting full zeronet? Sometimes I have to restart tor …

topic.title: frames and static content
topic.body: Is there a way to tell zeronet not to frame specific files, like in the content.json? Could be interesting for files you want to download and parse with third party programs. Like curl, git …

topic.title: Zite development
topic.body:
This is an subboard for technical discussions.

HTML, CSS, JavaScript, CoffeeScript etc.

topic.title: How is the debug compiler supposed to work?
topic.body:
I checked out ZeroTalk sources and tried to run them, but the coffescript compiler just tells me, that there is no jQuery and no window. What did I do wrong?

I modified content.json, published content.json and data/user/content.json and changed access privileges, so that zeronet can read and write all files.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k_12

topic.title: Translations
topic.body:
Just an idea how to split code and text, which would make translation easier. I chose arrays, because it seemed like being the simplest and fastest solution to me.

The less we have to modify the easier it is keeping cloned sites up to date.


Paste: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1MgHVPCE1ve6QfKrgsqCURzRj72HrRWioz/?1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k_14 (proof of concept)


I used it here: http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GEReDEwgi2JKjGXF2NmB4DvYsKWCETfbG/ (Partly German)

Just modified TopicList.coffee for now.

Or disallow your browser to access external websites.

> [musickiller](#comment_82_15NScazvsCHNmiXi6o6nvaMiwjeJYizgZQ): how exactly? (any browser example will do)

In icecat (firefox fork) I just set an invalid proxy and exluded 127.0.0.1 from using a proxy.

I also an own profile with all addons disabled. See `firefox --profilemanager` and [ProfileSwitcher addon](https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/profileswitcher/). You can also disable all plugins this way, which I didn't … just have Gecko Media Player.

And since all profiles work indepently, you can run it besides another firefox instance or set Kaffiene as your search engine etc.

1_19R2USgb9vPyg1jPQEJkGVoBwDuDcEmHRF.body:
> ## Why is this cool?
> Imagine a video site like YouTube, where **visitors** ***help*** **to host the site's content**.

> ## How does WebTorrent work?
> The WebTorrent protocol works just like BitTorrent protocol, except it uses WebRTC instead of TCP/uTP as the transport protocol.

> ## Can WebTorrent clients on different websites connect to each other?
> Yes! WebTorrent works across the entire web. WebTorrent clients running on one domain can connect to clients on any other domain. No silos!

https://webtorrent.io/faq

You basically seed your cache, therefor it's illegal if you watch illegal content unlike regular streaming.

5_1LRrd96P7FiTcsyNXVzPM5jtpQoH1B4gYf.body:

> Wikis can be used for taking notes and storing snippets, to create FAQs and documentation, to keep track of your goals or as a simple To-Do list.

I think NullPaste and ZeroTodo are more suitable for that

---
Let the edit wars begin

Please support `[[wikisite|alternative naming]]` and `#tags` / categories

---

Proposal: use `[☇]()` to link also to the real address if you use a .bit-address

---

made [ZeroPolls](http://127.0.0.1:43110/138R53t3ZW7KDfSfxVpWUsMXgwUnsDNXLP/?Page:ZeroPolls)

> [kaffie](#comment_75_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Just an FYI, the capital urls lead back to the homepage. I copied the content and put it into the proper zeropolls page. Should probably rollback the homepage.

oh … oh … that's bad … m'kay

> [ekaterina](#comment_116_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): The ☇ doesn't show up in my Tor Browser on Linux, shows the missing Unicode symbol instead, so I'd be for a different symbol that is supported by more browsers / operating systems.

Do some of those 9 work? ⭸ 🡖 ⭝ ⮩ 🞆 ┇ ▚ 🖰 📎

Preferebly an arrow to the bottom right as oppossed to the arrow to the upper right wikipedia uses for external links.

> [ekaterina](#comment_117_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): ┇ ▚  📎 These three work, the others don't. From left to right I see a vertical dashed line, a checkerboard pattern and a paperclip.

Then I guess using the paper clip (📎) as a permalink symbol would be the most intuitive solution. The other two symbols look too weird in an article.
using cc-by-sa like wikipedia would make sense https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Text_of_Creative_Commons_Attribution-ShareAlike_3.0_Unported_License

> The most popular is Kaffiene.

> Kaffiene has enabled cloning to encourage competition and growth amongst ZeroNet search engines.

You instantly know when an article is authored by @Kaffie.

---

> Free software is software that comes with permission for anyone to use, copy, and/or distribute, either verbatim or with modifications, either gratis or for a fee.

> The term “open source” software is used by some people to mean more or less the same category as free software. It is not exactly the same class of software: they accept some licenses that we consider too restrictive, and there are free software licenses they have not accepted. However, the differences in extension of the category are small: nearly all free software is open source, and nearly all open source software is free.

-> https://www.gnu.org/philosophy/categories.html

It does mean you can redistribute it, but the name itself does not imply that. It would be best for the network to release all zites as *free / libre open source software* though…

> [kaffie](#comment_80_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): 
> Huh. It'd be kind of silly to have a decentralized web where you're not allowed to copy things.

Most people just don't give a shit or don't know better. Even though it does need such little effort to make perfectly legal. (same as using creative commons licenses on ZeroBlogs and on ZeroWiki)

> [ekaterina](#comment_122_1Mk5sVKeCrwMc3wSD11jM7DZTiqF5D9BaD): ZeroBoard however actually sends posts through a PHP script on a normal web server. 

That might explain why ZeroBoard does not work any longer for me, I only allow 127.0.0.1
and most people would probably be annoyed if they got asked because of every littleness
and as always the Russians are rushin' ahead

6_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh.body:
> [kaffie](#comment_85_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): 
> As a side note, I was wondering if you knew of any light weight linux distros that come with the various P2P stuff preinstalled? Seems like another project that should be started, if it hasn't already. Having an easily deployable, lightweight OS that can connect to and help expand a decentralized meshnet+zeronet seems like it'd do wonders. Package that with a raspberry pi, or some other cheap PC, or maybe make it a liveboot USB and you've got an internet revolution kickstarted.

http://project-byzantium.org/ tries to do this

> Ad-hoc wireless mesh networking for the zombie apocalypse

from the FAQs:

> The goal of Byzantium is to develop and maintain a distribution of Linux  which can run from removable media (such as a CD-ROM, DVD-ROM, or USB storage device) without needing to be installed.  This distribution of Linux will include a graphical desktop, a control panel application which configures and manipulates services running on the Byzantium node, and mesh routing software which allows the creation of an entirely separate wireless Internet, functionally indistinguishable from a wireless access point of the sort that you’d find in a coffee shop or at home.

> [pycole](#comment_76_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): even if that somehow happened, there are dozens more trackers available, and it's certainly possible to run one yourself


      --trackers [protocol://address [protocol://address ...]]
      --trackers_file path  Load torrent trackers dynamically from a file

> [error404](#comment_5_1CWttfFnJgQmZifX8FbZn9dZ3xaTfooSJd): does the ZeroNet uses the same trackers as the bittorrent network?

Yes, those with udp:// and http:// look like regular bittorent trackers. I know coppersurfer.tk and leechers-paradies.org.

The two zero://*:15441 looks rather like zeronet nodes, at least that's the port zeronet usually uses.

So do regular nodes already exchange .onion- and ip-addresses with nodes they know?

1_1EgYg1XAxktqWHWC1aTWQoToF6Mr5QmEWq.body:
This probably can happen if you modify your data.json, topics are simply numbered consecutively … it has a field ‘"next_topic_id": 2,’

You could overwrite older data this way, but not sure though

Maybe you deleted your whole data.json and signed that?

> [jamesheald](#comment_2_1EgYg1XAxktqWHWC1aTWQoToF6Mr5QmEWq): http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1EgYg1XAxktqWHWC1aTWQoToF6Mr5QmEWq/How+will+we+end+up+handling+big+amounts+of+data
> Seems to link to this post? This is so bizarre, you can access this same post from the link above and this http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1EgYg1XAxktqWHWC1aTWQoToF6Mr5QmEWq/Transfered+my+users+json+to+my+laptop+but+can+t+access+my+ZeroMail. Interesting that they both seem to have the same key.
> Perhaps it has something to do with the fact that both my desktop and my laptop are both online with the ZeroNet right now?

Did you also transfer the content.json and data.json of zerotalk? If did not get them via the network **you will overwrite** your old content. Zeronet creates a new one, sign it, publish it and the other clients overwrite the old date with the update

the URLs are ?Topic:<index>_<user>/<irrelevant headline> the headline is just there to make it more readable, you could also link to http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1_1EgYg1XAxktqWHWC1aTWQoToF6Mr5QmEWq/I+Suck+Dicks

9_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body:
{
      "body": "Articles about Bitcoin, Torrent and Peer To Peer networks", 
      "added": 1436262090, 
      "type": "group", 
      "topic_id": 1, 
      "title": "P2P news flow"
    }, 

you probably have to go to your user folder manually and add the `"type": "group", ` to your data.json

`nano data/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/data/users/1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8/data.json`

and you have to obviously sign it afterwards … editing a topic / comment here should also do

I'm used to asynchronous and chronological wrongly sorted discussions.

Thanks to diaspora* - the social notwork

10_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body:
You can move your old topic.

Take a look at `nano data/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/data/users/1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8/data.json`

Just add `,"parent_topic_uri": "3_1PVcdu7USZH2kHMETbqDYLPjJZKCDWM52k"` to your old topic. As soon as you make your next change through the ZeroTalk ‘interface’ it will be signed and published.

If you succeed you can rename this to ‘How to move a topic’
Well I also thought this, but then I just took a look at the data.json. ‘stickied’ on the other hand can be configured only by the owner.

11_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body: Yeah, took me also some days to figure that out.

6_1DcDDitsjFJohvwonPmpibRChmA7uGxqL7.body: Well this could be cool if you have a central image hoster or something like ZeroCDN. But this could result in a single point of failure, as soon as the owners of the hosters clear their zites, this would affect a lot other. On the other hand you maybe could have a central imagehoster who is capable of uploading images to your own zite and later linking to it would be rather cool. This on the other hand could result in freenet-like behavior, where freesites include images of others just to keep them alive. You would need to block zites intentionally.

Regular cooking book … because during a Zombieapocalypse with only a mashnet and zeronet left, we totally need this to survive. Should focus on food you can grow yourselft, though.

Github like zite that can visualize a git repository, also support issues and stuff. Cloning and pulling should be possible. Pushing won't work.

Zite that can generate a magnet link and torrent file for an uploaded file.

> [aoi](#comment_1_13NJuU9nw3cFSVoETCkN6BCv5s5v5V2ngA): A forum for sites like play or zerotorrent, I like the downloads but miss the community

Just clone ZeroTalk …

> [klauszimmermann](#comment_34_15QGRquMETTn5LnCHjTm1qa9eaXGtq7gpT): A library full of free (or freed) ebooks.
> All other "ebook sites" around here simply link to somewhere else that has the stuff. Why are people afraid of hosting them? Is hard drive space an issue? Unlike movies or games, I think ebooks are small enough to be hosted here.

Well you could classify them as optional. But linking existing torrents (magnet link) could also make sense, if there are already such. Also different zites can link the same content this way and it's shared more efficiently. But weblinks do not make sense, agree with that.

Project Gutenberg only has their [archive ISOs](https://www.gutenberg.org/wiki/Gutenberg:The_CD_and_DVD_Project#Downloading_Via_BitTorrent) as torrents, though. Might be worth it to mirror that site or copy their content into an independant index.

15_1CMYxdit4qq9QGk9DYRu2ruRPd2YDGckH8.body:
We can't stop them, therefore we have to ignore them. No feeding, no flaming.

We can moderate boards, but that won't stop anyone from reposting and creating trash accounts.

7_17n5jg4bBEoWodXDf8L4Y2u88ShagS272Y.body:
this might be faster:

    query = """
      SELECT json.directory, keyvalue.value AS cert_user_id FROM json 
      LEFT JOIN keyvalue ON (keyvalue.key = 'cert_user_id' AND keyvalue.json_id = json.json_id)
      WHERE directory = 'users/#{auth_address}' AND file_name = 'content.json'
    """"
    @cmd "dbQuery", [query], (user) =>
      if user? && user.length == 1
        console.log("cert_user_id of #{auth_address}", user[0].cert_user_id)
       else 
         console.log("No such user: ", auth_address)

10_1MEWJRMLgvofqG9Mbsb2Rc4hFFyv7HeRx7.body:
I wouldn't call ZeroNet as such, because it is even though it's probably not indexable (much JavaScript) pretty easy to use for average users. You can use ZeroNet use via a proxy without noteworthy cutbacks. You can also easily link it from clearnet sites. (which I already did)

I also think it's just a matter of time until meta search engines like searx are able to use search engines within TOR and ZeroNet.

They just need to run a node and could let the user choose wherther links go to a proxy or to the local node.

> [pycole](#comment_94_1KwTTgPRSTHFmmJAFBt6kQfdyNeSM5KJuH): You can browse tor via proxy too: here's the onion mirror of Bluish Coder's site run by the onion.to service. And for even more weirdness, here's a proxy into tor that points to a proxy into zeronet (It doesn't seem to work, but it's still neat).

I’m aware of that, my last sentence was meant for both ZeroNet and TOR

https://zerowrohotccypak.onion.cab/ and http://zerowrohotccypak.onion.link/ also don't work

1_1KRDb5SVJe8Gjy9eYEQz62tJv73vavZdUn.body:
If I understood it right, some zites (mail echoboard, board) use a node like a server. But I think you should avoid this.

Most sides are basically client side + read/write/sign/publish files through the ZeroFrame API, which is the magic you need for interactive sites.

http://127.0.0.1:43110/17Kom2G5qNDc6NaQwv445h1gFzxkY3ZtZe/site_development/zeroframe_api_reference/

6_18rFd7W9y5QGQEVXaCoJV7jyt7D8aN156h.body:
As you see here, it will never work on all clients. And if I see a zite with no content or which is totally broken, I delete it right away.

Like ZeroBoard for example or that one zite that embedded porn from imgur.

But it’s not zeronet doing these requests, it’s your browser.

1_1L5rGDgTs4W2V7gekSvJNhKa7XaHkVwotD.body:
You can telll zeronet which browser it shall use `--open_browser [browser_name]`

But this won’t fix your other problem. Normal browser is able to connect to zn?

Maybe related to this: https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/ticket/11493

The addresse looks right, but give it up. I was able to connect to my already running ZeroNet node with torbrowser. Can’t test `--open_browser` since I don’t want to run my browser with zeronet user.

If you expect some help you should also always present the exact error messages.

(can’t reproduce since I don’t use bundles)

---

It seems TOR browser is not meant to be used without TOR.

> The design document says:
> The browser MUST NOT bypass Tor proxy settings for any content.

Better try to install TOR via your distro’s repo and use a real daemon for that. If you depend on torbrowser for TOR, it will probably not work, I expect it to start the browser after connection is established … this means it already detected TOR as non-working at this point.
